title: Are there persons of Hungarian origin that made significant contributions to the modern Romanian culture? - Quora

response.answer_text: Yes. I’d start with the Hungarian prince of Transylvania, Gabriel Bethlen (Bethlen Gábor) - who supported the building of various schools for Romanians in Transylvania; the first known poem written in Romanian was written by a guy who studied in one of these schools, IIRC - , but I doubt his accomplishments in relation to Romanians would be considered part of the modern period. The Hungarian composer Béla Bartók also comes to mind, one of the founders of ethnomusicology; he kinda put the (Western) Romanian folklore on the musical map. Feel free to listen to his Romanian Folk Dances if you don’t believe me. Sure, his contribution was an indirect one but it should still count. Carol Pop de Szathmari, (Szathmáry Pap Károly) considered to be the world's first combat photographer and first world (known) combat reporter. Became the Romanian Royal House’s (first?) official photographer. József Sebestyén, created the interwar Romanian Coat of Arms on which the current one is based on. Vida Géza, who was a famous sculptor of the communist period. In the sports area, besides the ones mentioned already by Mr. Marinescu in his answer, I’d like to add Béla and Márta Károlyi, who had significant results as head coaches of the Romanian Olympic Women’s Gymnast team (most notably, Nadia Comaneci’s first-ever perfect 10 in the 1976 Summer Montreal Olympics). They also trained Ecaterina Szabo (Szabó Katalin) yet another great Romanian gymnast most famous for her tremendous effort at the 1984 Los Angeles Summer Olympics. Moving on to footbal, one cannot forget that the 1986’s European Champions’ Cup Winners, Steaua Bucharest, besides being coached by a certain Emerich Jenei (Jenei Imre)it also featured another Hungarian ethnic, László Bölöni (considered one of the best Romanian footballers ever). Special mentions: 19th century’s Károly Ács (The Elder), Koós Ferenc or Árpád Bitay’s work did not influence Romanian modern (and folk) culture directly, but tried to expose Hungarians to it, by translating it into Hungarian. Same goes for Veress Sándor (founder of the Romanian cartography) and his son, Veress Endre. Also I’d like to add the Rimanóczy architects, Kálmán Sr. and his son, Kálmán Jr. Again, their contribution is not intentional or direct, but my hometown would not look the way it looks today, without their work. PS: How could I forget Mr. Szabolcs Cseh, probably the best Romanian stuntman seen in Romanian films. (mainly pre-1990 ones). He established the first Romanian professional stuntmen team, while previously being the first professional fight coordinator (hired for that position) and has worked on probably every action scene in a Romanian film in the communist period and many afterwards (about 150+ films and TV projects).

There is an interesting confusion and overlapping in all this. Romanians tend to consider great athletes and other significant, high-profile people of Hungarian background, mother tongue and identity, living in Romania, as Romanians, sometimes as a compromise adding “of Hungarian origin”. This is why - to maintain the facade of the homogeneous Romanian nation-state - these people were forced, mostly against their will, to change their names to its Romanian version and Szabó Katalin was known in the world as Ecaterina Szabo, Balázs Jolán back in the 60s as Iolanda Balas, Bölöni László as Ladislau Boloni and Jenei Imre as Emerich Jenei, to name just a few. While - still maintaining that the borders of the Hungarian nation and state do not coincide - in Hungary by many they were considered as Hungarians and seen with a sympathy reserved usually for co-nationals. Romanians, however, also tend to think that the borders of the Romanian nation and state do not coincide, while covering all present day Romania they extend to neighboring countries, mostly to Moldova which has a significant Romanian(speaking) majority. These most Romanians consider as part of the Romanian nation, even if at present outside the actual state borders. (While, in somewhat contradicting terms they tend to reject the idea that, for example, the Szekely community, in the very middle of Romania, would in any sense be part of the Hungarian nation.) Quite confusing, is it not?
